very proude, reuengefull, ambitious, with moe offences at my becke,
then I haue thoughts to put them in, imaginatiōimagination to giue them shape,
or time to act them in: what should such fellowes as I do crauling be­
tweene earth and heauen? we are arrant knaues, beleeue none of vs.
go thy waies to a Nunry, Wher's your father?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: At home my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Let the doers be shut vpon him,
That he may play the foole no where but in's owne house,
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: O helpe him you sweet heauens.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
If thou doost marry, Ile giue thee this plage for thy dow­
rie, be thou as chast as yce, as pure as snow, thou shalt not escape ca­
lumny get thee to a Nunry, farewell. Or if thou wilt needs marry,
marry a foole, for wise men know well enough what monsters you
make of them: to a Nunry goe, and quickly to, farwell.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: Heauenly powers restore him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I haue heard of your paintings well enough, God hath gi­
uen you one face, and you make your selfes another, you gig and am­
ble, and you list you nickname Gods creaturs, and make your wan­
tonnes ignorance; goe to, Ile no more on't, it hath made me madde,
I say we will haue no mo marriage, those that are married already, all
but one shal liue, the rest shall keep as they are: to a Nunry go.Exit,

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: O what a noble mind is heere othrowne!
The courtiers, souldiers, schollers, eye, tongue, sword,
Th'expectation, and Rose of the faire state,
The glasse of fashion, and the mould of forme,
Th'obseru'd of all obseruers, quite, quite downe,
And I of Ladies most deiect and wretched,
That suckt the huny of his musickt vowes;
Now see what noble and most soueraigne reason
Like sweet bells iangled out of time, and harsh,
That vnmatcht forme, and stature of blowne youth
Blasted with extacy. O wo is me
T'haue seene what I haue seene, see what I see.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Loue: his affections doe not that way tend,
Nor what he spake, though it lackt forme a little,
Was not like madnes; there's something in his soule
Ore which his melancholy sits on brood,
And I doe doubt, the hatch and the disclose
Will be some danger; which for to preuent,
I haue in quick determination
Thus set downe: he shall with speed to England,
For the demaund of our neglected tribute,
Haply the seas, and countries different,
With variable obiects, shall expell
This something setled matter in his hart,
Whereon his braines still beating
Puts him thus from fashion of himselfe.
What thinke you on't?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: It shall doe well.
But yet doe I beleeue the origen and comencement of it
Sprung from neglected loue: how now Ophelia?
You neede not tell vs what Lord Hamlet said,
We heard it all: my Lord, doe as you please,
But if you hold it fit, after the play.
Let his Qeene‐mother all alone intreate him
To show his griefe, let her be round with him,
And Ile be plac'd (so please you) in the eare
Of all their conference: if she find him not,
To England send him: or confine him where
Your wisedome best shall thinke.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It shall be so,
Madnes in great ones must not vnmatcht goe.Exeunt.

div2.stage: Enter Hamlet, and three of the Players.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Speake the speech I pray you as I pronounc'd it to you, trip­
pingly on the tongue, but if you mouth it as many of our Players do,
I had as liue the towne cryer spoke my lines, nor doe not saw the aire
too much with your hand thus, but vse all gently, for in the very tor­
rent tempest, and as I may say, whirlwind of your passion, you must
acquire and beget a temperance, that may giue it smoothnesse, O it
offends me to the soule, to heare a robustious perwig‐pated fellow tere
Prince of Denmarke. tere a passion to totters, to very rags, to spleet the eares of the ground
lings, who for the most part are capable of nothing but inexplicable
dumbe shewes, and noyse: I would haue such a fellow whipt for ore­
dooing Termagant, it out Herods Herod, pray you auoyde it.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: I warrant your honour.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Be not too tame neither, but let your own e discretion be
your tutor, sute the action to the word, the word to the action, with
this speciall obseruance, that you ore‐steppe not the modesty of na­
ture: For any thing so ore‐doone, is from the purpose of playing,
whose end both at the first, and now, was and is, to hold as twere
the Mirrour vp to nature, to shew vertue her feature; score her own
Image, and the very age and body of the time his forme and pressure:
Now this ouer‐done, or come trady off, though it makes the vnskil­
full laugh, cannot but make the iudicious greeue, the censure of
which one, must in your allowance ore‐weigh a whole Theater of o­
thers. O there bee Players that I haue seene play, and heard others
praysd, and that highly, not to speake it prophanely, that neither ha­
uing th'accent of Christians, nor the gate of Christian, Pagan, nor
man, haue so rutted and bellowed, that I haue thought some of Na­
tures Iournemen had made men, and not made them well, they imita­
ted humanity so abominably.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: I hope we haue reform'd that indifferently with vs.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p:
O reforme it altogether, and let those that play your clownes
speake no more then is set downe for them, for there be of them that
will themselues laugh, to set on some quantity of barraine spectators
to laugh to, though in the meane time, some necessary question of
the play be then to be considered: that's villanous, and shewes a most
pittifull ambition in the foole that vses it: goe make you ready. How
now my Lord, will the King heare this peece of worke?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And the Queene to, and that presently,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Bid the Plaiers make hast. Wil you two help to hasten them.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I my LordExeunt those two.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What how, Horatio.Enter Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Heere sweete Lord, at your seruice.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Horatio, thou art een as iust a man
As ere my conuersation copt withall.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: O my deere Lord.
Nay, do not thinke I flatter,
For what aduancement may I hope from thee
That no reuenew hast but thy good spirits
To feede and cloathe thee, why should the poore be flattred?
No, let the candied tongue lick obsurd pompe,
And crooke the pregnant hinges of the knee
Where thrift may follow fauning, doost thou heare,
Since my deere soule was mistris of her choyce,
And could of men distinguish her election
Shath seald thee for her felfe, for thou hast beene
As one in suffering all that suffers nothing,
A man that Fortunes buffets and rewards
Hast tane with equall thankes; and blest are those
Wose bloud and iudgement are so well comedled,
That they are not a pipe for Fortunes finger
To sound what stoppe shee please: giue me that man
That is not passions slaue, and I will weare him
In my hearts core, I in my heart of heart
As I do thee. Something too much of this,
There is a play to night before the King,
One scene of it comes neere the circumstance
Which I haue told thee of my fathers death
I prethee when thou seest that act a foote,
Euen with the very comment of thy soule
Obserue my Vncle, if his occulted guilt
Doe not it selfe vnkennill in one speech,
It is a damned Ghost that wee haue seene,
And my imaginations are as foule
As Vulcans stithy; giue him heedfull note
For I mine eyes will riuet to his face,
And after wee will both our iudgements ioyne
In censure of his seemng.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Well my Lord,
If a steale ought the whilst this play is playing
And scape detected, I will pay the theft.

div2.stage:
Enter trumpets and Kettle Drummes, King, Queene,
Polonis, Ophelia.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: They are comming to the play. I must be idle,
Get you a place.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How fares our cousin Hamlet?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Excellent yfaith.
Of the Camelions dish, I eate the ayre,
Promis‐cram'd, you cannot feede Capons so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I haue nothing with this aunswer Hamlet,
These words are not mine.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No, nor mine now my Lord.
You playd once i'th Vniuersity you say,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: That did I my Lord, and was accounted a good Actor,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What did you enact?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I did enact Iulius Cæsar, I was kild i'th Capitall,
Brutus kild me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It was a brute part of him to kill so Capitall a calfe there.
Be the Players ready?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I my Lord, they stay vpon your patience.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Come hether my deare Hamlet, sit by me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No good mother heere's mettle more attraiue.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: O, oh, doe you marke that.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Lady shall I lie in your lap?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Doe you thinke I meant country matters?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: I thinke nothing my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: That's a faire thought to lye betweene maydes legs.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: What is my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: You are merry my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Who I?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.l: I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
O God! your onely Iigge‐maker, what should a man do but
be merry, for looke you how cheerfully my Mother lookes, and my
father died within's two howres.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: Nay, tis twice two months my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham,
sp.p:
So long, nay then let the diuell weare blacke, for Ile haue a
sute of sables; O heauens, die two months ago, and not forgotten yet,
then there's hope a great mans memory may out‐liue his life halfe a
yeare, but ber Lady a must build Churches then, or else shall a suffer
not thinking on, with the Hobby‐horse, whose Epitaph is, for O, for
O, the hobby‐horse is forgot.

div2.stage:
The Trumpets sound. Dumbe show followes.
Enter a King and a Queene, the Queene embracing him, and he her he
takes her vp, and declines his head vppon her necke, he lies him downe vp­
pon a bancke of flowers, she seeing him a sleepe, leaues him: anon comes in
an other man, take's off his crowne, kisses it, pours poyson in the sleepers
eares, and leaues him: the Queene returnes, finds the King dead, makes
passionate action, the poysoner with some three or foure comes in againe,
seeme to condole with her, the dead body is carried away, the poisoner woes
the Queene with gifts, she seemes harsh awhile but in the end accepts loue.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.l: What meanes this my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Marry tis munching Mallico, it meanes mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.l: Belike this show imports the argument of the play.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: We shall know by this fellow,Enter prologue.
The players cannot keepe they'le tell all.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: Will a tell us what this show meant?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I or any show that you will show him, be not you asham'd
to show heele not shame to tell you what it meanes.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.l: You are naught, you are naught, Ile marke the play.

sp.speaker: Prologue.
sp.l: For vs and for our Tragedie,
Heere stooping to your clemencie,
We begge your hearing patiently.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Is this a Prologue or the posie of a ing?

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: Tis breefe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: As womans loue.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Full thirty times hath Phœbus Cart gone round
Neptunes salt wash, and Tellus orb'd the ground,
And thirty dosen moones with borrowed sheene
About the world haue times twelue thirties beene
Since loue our hearts, and Hymen did our hands
Vnite comutuall in most sacred bands,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: So many iourneyes may the Sunne and Moone
Make vs againe count ore ere loue bee doone,
But woe is me you are so sicke of late,
So farre from cheere, and from your former state,
That I distrust you, yet though I distrust,
Discomfort you my Lord it nothing must.
For women feare too much, euen as they loue,
And womens feare and loue hold quantity,
Either none, in neither ought, or in extremity,
Now what my Lord is proofe hath made you know,
And as my loue is ciz'st, my feare is so,
Where loue is great, the litlest doubts are feare,
Where little feares grow great, great loue growes there.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Faith I must leaue thee loue, and shortly to,
My operant powers their functions leaue to d,
And thou shalt liue in this fare world behind,
Honord, belou'd, and haply one as kind,
For husband shalt thou.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: O confound the rest.
Such loue must needes be treason in my brest,
In second husband let me be accurst,
None wed the second, but who kild the first.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
That's
wormwood.
The instances that second marriage moue
Are base respects of thrift, but none of loue,
A second time I kill my husband dead,
When second husband kisses me in bed.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I doe beleeue you thinke what now you speake,
But what we doe determine, oft we breake,
Purpose is but the slaue to memory,
Of violent birth, but poore validity,
Which now the fruite vnripe sticks on the tree,
But fall vnshaken when they mellow bee.
Most necessary tis that we forget
To pay our selues what to our selues is debt,
What to our selues in passion we propose,
The passion ending, doth the purpose lose,
The violence of either, griefe, or ioy,
Their owne ennactures with themselues destroy,
Where ioy most reuels, griefe doth most lament,
Greefe ioy, ioy griefes, on flender accedent,
This world is not for aye, nor tis not strange,
That euen our loues should with our fortunes change,
For tis a question left vs yet to proue,
Whether loue lead fortune, or else fortune loue.
The great man downe, you marke his fauourite flies,
The poore aduanced makes iends of enemies,
And hethertoo doth loue on fortune tend,
For who not needs, shall neuer lacke a friend,
And who in want a hollow friend doth try,
Directly seasons him his enemie.
But orderly to end where I begunne,
Our willes and fates doe so contrary runne,
That our deuices still are ouerthrowne,
Our thoughts are ours, their ends none of our owne,
So thinke thou wilt no second husband wed,
But die thy thoughts when thy first Lord is dead.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Nor earth to me giue foode, nor heauen light,
Sport and repose lock from mee day, and night,
To desperation turne my trust and hope,
And Anchors cheere in prison be my scope,
Each opposite that blanckes the face of ioy,
Meete what I would haue well, and it destroy,
Both heere and hence pursue me lasting strife,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
If she should
breake it now
If once I bee a widdow, euer I be a wife.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tis deepely sworne, sweet leaue mee heare a while,
My spirits grow dull and faine I would beguyle
The tedious day with sleepe,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Sleepe rock thy braine,
And neuer come mischance betwixt vs twane.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Maddam, how like you this play?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: The Lady doth protest too much me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O but shee'le keepe her word.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Haue you heard the argument? is there no offence in't?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No, no, they do but iest, poyson in iest, no offence ith world.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What do you call the play?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
The Mousetrap, mary how tropically, this play is the Image
of a murther done in Vienna, Gonzago is the Dukes name, his wife
Baptista, you shall see anone, tis a knauish peece of worke, but what
of that? your maiesty and we shall haue free soules, it touches vs not,
let the gauled Iade winch, our withers are vnwrung. This is one Lu­
cianus, Nephew to the King.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.l: You are as good as a Chorus my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I could interpret betweene you and your loue
If I could see the puppits dallying.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: You are keene my Lord, you are keene.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It would cost you a groning to take off mine edge.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.l: Still better and worse.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
So you mistake your husbands. Beginne murtherer, leaue
thy damnable faces and begin, come, the croking Rauen doth bel­
low for reuenge.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thoughts black, hands apt, drugges fit and time agreeing,
Considerat season els no creature seeing,
Thou mixture rancke, of midnight weeds collected,
With Hecats ban thrice blasted, thrice infected,
Thy naturall magicke, and die property,
On wholesome life vsurps immediately.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
A poysons him i'th Garden for his estate, his names Gonza­
go, the story is extant and written in very choice Italian, you shall see
anon how the murtherer gets the loue of Gonzagoes wife.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.l: The King rises.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: How fares my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Giue ore the play.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Giue me some light, away.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Lights, lights, lights.Exeunt, all but Ham. and Horatio.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why let the stroken deere goe weepe,
The Hart vngauled play,
For some must watch whilst some must sleepe,
sp.p:
Thus runnes the world away. Would not this sir and a forrest of fea­
thers, if the rest of my fortunes turne Turke with me, with prouinci­
all Roses, on my raz'd shooes, get me a fellowship in a city of players?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Halfe a share.

sp.speaker: Ham,
sp.l: A whole one I.
For thou dost know oh Damon deere
This Realme dimantled was
Of Ioue himselfe, and now raignes heere
A very very paiok.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: You might haue rim'd.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
O good Horatio, Ile take the Ghosts word for a thousand
pound. Didst perceaue?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Very well my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Vppon the talke of the poysoning.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I did very well note him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Ah ha, come some musique, com the Recorders,
For if the King like not the Comedy,
Why then belike he likes it not perdy.
Come, some musique,

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: Good my Lord, voutsafe me a word with you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Sir a whole history.

sp.speaker: Guy.
sp.l: The King sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I sir, what of him?

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: Is in his retirement meruailous distempred.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: With drinke fir?

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: No my lord, with choller,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Your wisedome should shew it selfe more richer to signifie
this to the Doctor, for, for me to put him to his purgation, would per­
haps plunge him into more choller.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: Good my Lord put your discourse into some frame,
And stare not so wildly from my affaire.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I am tame sir, pronounce.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.l:
The Queene your mother in most great affliction of spirit,
hath sent me to you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: You are welcome.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.p:
Nay good my Lord, this curtesie is not of the right breed, if
it shall please you to make me a wholsome aunswer, I will doe your
mothers commaundement, if not, your patdon and my returne, shall
be the end of busines.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Sir I cannot.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Make you a wholsome answer, my wits diseasd, but sir, such
answere as I can make, you shall commaund, or rather as you say, my
mother, therefore no more, but to the matter, my mother you say.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l:
Then thus she saies, your behauiour hath strooke her into a­
mazement and admiration.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
O wonderfull sonne that can so stonish a mother! but is
there no sequell at the heeles of this mothers admiration? impart.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: She desires to speake with you in her closet ere you go to bed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
We shall obey, were she ten times our mother, haue you any
further trade with vs?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: my Lord you once did loue me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: And doe still by these pickers and stealers.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
Good my Lord, what is your cause of distemper, you do sure­
ly barre the doore vpon your owne liberty, if you deny your griefes
to your friend.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Sir I lacke aduancement.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p:
How can that be when you haue the voyce of the King him­
selfe for your succession in Denmarke.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I si, but while the grasse growes, the prouerbe is something
musty, oh the Recorders, let me see one, to withdraw with you, why
do you goe about to recouer the wind of me, as if you would driue
me into a toyle?

sp.speaker: Guyl
sp.l: O my lord if my duty be too bold, my loue is too vnmanerly.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I do not well vnderstand that, will you play vpon this pipe?

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: My Lord I cannot.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I pray you.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: Beleeue me I cannot.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: I know no touch of it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
It is as easie as lying; gouerne these ventages with your fin­
gers, and the thumb giue it breath with your mouth, and it will dis­
course most eloquent musique, looke you, these are the stoppes.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: But these cannot I commaund to any vtrance of harmonie,
I haue not the skill.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Why looke you now how vnworthy a thing you make of
me, you would play vpon me, you would seeme to know my stops,
you would plucke out the hart of my misterie, you would sound mee
from my lowest note to my compasse, and there is much musique ex­
cellētexcellent voice in this little organ, yet cannot you make it speak, s'blood
do you thinke I am easier to be plaid on then a pipe, call me what in­
strument ou wil, though you fret me not, you cannot play vpon me.
God blesse you sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: My Lord the Queene woud speake with you, & presently.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Do you see yonder cloud that's almost in shape of a Camel?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: By'th masse and tis like a Camell indeede,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Me thinkes it is like a Wezell.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: It is black like a Wezell.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Or like a Whale.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Very like a Whale.
Then I will come to my mother by and by,
They foole me to the top of my bent, I will come by and by,
Leaue me friends.
I will, say so. By and by is easily said,
Tis now the very witching time of night,
When Churchyards yawne, and hell it selfe breakes out
Contagion to this world: now could I drinke hote blood,
And doe such businesse as the bitter day
Would quake to looke on: soft, now to my mother,
O hart loose not thy nature! let not euer,
The soule of Nero enter this firme bosome!
Let me be cruell, not vnnaturall,
I will speake dagger to her, but vse none,
My tongue and soule in this be hypocrites,
How in my words someuer se be shent,
To giue them seales neuer my soule consent.Exit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I like him not, nor stands it safe with vs
To let his madnesse range, therefore prepare you,
I your commission will forth‐with dispatch,
And he to England shall along with you,
The termes of our estate may not endure
Hazerd so neer's as doth hourely grow,
Out of his browes.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: We will our selues prouide,
Most holy and religious feare it is
To keepe those many many bodies safe
That liue and feed vpon your Maiesty.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: The single and peculier life is bound,
With all the strength and armour of the mind
To keepe it selfe from noyance, but much more
That spirit, vpon whose wele depends and rests
The liues of many, the cesse of Maiesty
Dies not alone; but like a gulfe doth draw
What's neere it, with it, or it is a massie wheele
Fixt on the somnet of the highest mount,
To whose hugh spokes, tenn thousand lessr things
Are morteist and adioynd, which when it falls
Each small annexment, pety consequenc
Attends the boystrous raine, neuer alone
Did the King sigh, but a generall growne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Arme you I pray you to this speedy voi age,
For we will fetters put about this feare
Which now goes too free‐footed.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: We will hast vs.Exeunt Gent.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: My Lord, he's going to his mothers closet,
Behind the Arras I'le conuay my selfe
To here the prossesse, I'le warrant shee'le tax him home,
And as you said, and wisely was it sayd,
Tis eete that some more audience then a mother,
Since ature makes them partiall, should ore‐heare
The speech of vantage; fare you well my Leige,
I'le call vpon you ere you goe to bed.
And tell you what I know.Exit

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thankes deere my Lord.
O my offence is rancke, it smels to heauen,
It hath the primall eldest curse vppont,
A brothers murther, pray can I not,
Though inclination be as sharp as will,
My stronger guilt defeats my stronge entent,
And like a man to double busines bound,
I stand in pause where I shall first beginne,
And both neglect: what if this cursed hand
Were thicker then it selfe with brothers blood,
Is there not raine enough in the sweete Heauens
To wash it white as snow? whereto serues mercy
But to confront the visage of offence?
And what's in praier but this two‐fold force,
To be forestalled ere we come to fall,
Or pardon being downe, then Ile looke vp.
My faults is past, but oh! what forme of prayer
Can serue my turne? forgiue me my foule murther;
That cannot be since I am still possest
Of those affects for which I did the murther;
My Crowne, mine owne ambition, and my Queene;
May one be pardoned and retaine th'offence?
In the corupted currents of this world,
Offences guided hand may show by iustice,
And oft tis seene the wicked prize it selfe
Buyes out the law, but tis not so aboue,
There is no shufling, there the action lies
In his true nature, and we our selues compeld
Euen to the teeth and forehead of our faults
To giue in euidence, what then, what rests,
Try what repentance can, what can it not,
Yet what can it, when one cannot repent?
O wretched state, O bosome blacke as death,
O limed soule, that struggling to be free,
Art more idgaged; helpe Angles make assay,
Bow stubborne knees and hart with strings of steele,
Be soft as sinnewes of the new borne babe,
All may be well.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Now might I doe it, bot now a is a praying,
And now Ile doo't, and so goes to heauen,
And so am I reuendge, that would be scand
A villaine kills my father, and for that,
I his sole sonne, doe this same villaine send
To heauen.
Why, this is base and silly. ––––––––– not reuendge,
A tooke my father grosely full of bread,
Withall his crimes broad blowne, as flush as May,
And how his audit stands who knowes saue heauen,
But in our circumstance and course of thought,
Tis heauy with him: and am I then reuendged
To take him in the purging of his soule,
When he is fit and seasoned for his passage?
No,
Vp sword, and know thou a more horrid hent,
When he is drunke, a sleepe, or in his rage,
Or in th'incestious pleasure of his bed,
At game, a swearing, or about some act
That has no relish of saluation in't.
Then trip him that his heele mas kick at heauen,
And that his soule may be as damnd and blacke
As hell whereto it goes; my mother staies,
This phisicke but prolongs thy sickly daies.Exit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My words fly vp, my thoughts remaine below
Words without thoughts neuer to heauen goe.Exit.

sp.speaker: Polo.
sp.l: A will come strait, looke you lay home to him,
Tell him his prancks haue beene too broad to beare with,
And that your grace hath screen'd and stood betweene
Much heate and him, Ile silence me euen heere,
Pray you be round.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Ile waite you, feare me not,
With‐draw, I heare him comming.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Now mother, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Hamlet, thou hast thy father much offended.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Mother you haue my father much offended.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Come, come, you answer with an idle tongue,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Goe goe, you question with a wicked tongue.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Why how now Hamlet?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Haue you forgot me?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No by the rood not so,
You are the Queene, your husbands brothers wife,
And would it were not so, you are my mother.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Nay then Ile set those to you that can speake.

sp.speaker: Ham,
sp.l: Come, come, and sit you downe, you shall not boudge,
You goe not till I set you vp a glasse
Where you may see the most part of you.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What wilt thou doe, thou wilt not murther me?
Helpe how.

sp.speaker: Polo,
sp.l: What how helpe.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How now, a Rat, dead for a Duckat, dead.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: O I am slaine.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O me, what hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay I know not, is it the King?

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.l: O what a rash and bloody deede is this.

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.l: A bloody deede, almost as bad good mother
As kill a King, and marry with his brother.

sp.speaker: Ger
sp.l: As kill a King.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I Lady, it was my word.
Thou wretched, rash, intruding foole farewell,
I tooke thee for thy better, take thy fortune,
Thou find'st to bee too busie is some danger.
Leaue wringing of your hands, peace sit you downe,
And let me wring your heart, for so I shall
If it be made of penetrable stuffe,
If damned custome haue nor brasd it so,
That it be proofe and bulwark against sence.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What haue I done, that thou dar'st waggc thy tongue
In noyse so rude against me?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Such an act
That blurres the grace and blush of modesty,
Calls vertue hipocrit, takes of the Rose
From the faire forhead of an innocent loue,
And sets a blister there, makes mariage vowes
As false as dicers oathes, Oh such a deed!
As from the body of contraction pluckes
The very soule: and sweet religion makes
A rapsody of words; heauens face dooes glow
Ore this solidiry and compound masse
With heated visage, as against the doome
Is thought‐sick at the act.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Ay me what act?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: That roares so low'de and thunders in the Index,
Looke here vpon this Picture, and on this,
The counterfeit presentment of two brothers,
See what a grace was feated on his browe,
Hiperions curles, the front of Ioue him‐selfe,
An eye like Mars, to threten and command,
A station like the herald Mercury,
New lighted on a heaue, a kissing hill,
A combination and fo rme indeede,
Where euery God didseeme to set his seale
To giue the world assurance of a man,
This was your husband, looke you now what followes,
Heer is your husband like a mildewed eare,
Blasting his wholesome brother: haue you eyes?
Could you on this faire mountaine leaue to feede,
And batton on this Moore; ha, haue you eyes?
You cannot call it loue, for at your age
The heyday in the blood is tame, it's humble,
And waites vpon the iudgement, and what iudgement
Would step from this to this? sence sure you haue
Els could you not haue motion, but sure that sence
Is appoplext, for madnesse would not erre
Nor senc to extacie was neere so thral'd
But it reseru'd some quantity of choyce
To serue in such a difference. What diuell wast
That thus hath cosond you at hodman‐blind?
Eyes without feeling, feeling without sight,
Eares without hands, or eyes, smelling sance all,
Or but a sickly part of one true sence
Could not so mope. Oh shame! where is thy blush?
Rebellious hell,
If thou canst mutine in a Matrons bones,
To flaming youth, let vertue be as wax
And melt in her owne fire, proclaime no shame
When the compulsiue ardure giues the charge,
Since frost it selfe as actiuely doth bune,
And reason pardons will.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O Hamlet speake no more,
Thou turn'st my very eyes into my soule,
And there I see such black and greeued spots
As will leaue there their tin'ct.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay but to liue
In the rancke sweat of an incestuous bed
Stewed in corruption, honying and making loue
Ouer the nasty stie.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O speake to mee no more,
These words like daggers enter in my eares,
No more sweet Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: A murtherer and a villaine,
A slaue that is not twentith part the kyth
Of your pedent Lord, a vice of Kings,
A cut purse of the Empire and the rule,
That from a shelfe the precious Diadem stole
And put it in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: A King of shreds and patches,
Saue me and houer ore me with your wings
You heauely gards: what would your gratious figure?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Alasse hee's mad.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Doe youe not come your tardy sonne to chide,
That lap'st in time and passion lets goe by
Th'important acting of your dread command. O say!

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.l: Doe not forget, this visitation
Is but to whet thy almost blunted purpose,
But looke, amazement on thy mother sits,
O step betweene her, and her sighing soule!
Conceit in weakest bodies strongest workes,
Speake to her Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How is it with you Lady?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Alasse how i'st with you?
That you doe bend your eye on vacancy.
And with th'incorporall ayre doe hold discourse,
Foorth at your eyes your spirrits wildly peep,
And as the sleeping souldiers in th'alarme,
Your beaded haire like life in excrements
Starts vp and stands an end: O gentle sonne!
Vpon the heate and flame of thy distemper
Sprinckle coole patience, whereon doe you looke?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: On him, on him, looke you how pale he glares,
His forme and cause conioyned, preaching to stones
Would make them capable, doe not looke vpon me,
Least with this pittious action you conuert
My stearne effects, then what I haue to doe
Will want true collour, teares perchance for blood.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: To whome doe you speake this?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Doe you see nothing there?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Nothing at all, yet all that is there I see.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nor did you nothing heare?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: No nothing but our selues.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why looke you there, looke how it steales away,
My father in his habit as he liues,
Looke where he goes, euen now out at the portall.Exit Ghost.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: This is the very coynage of your braine,
This bodilesse creation, extacy is very cunning in

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: My pulse as yours doth temperatly keepe time,
And makes as healthfull musicke, it is not madnesse
That I haue vttred, brin g me to the test,
And the matter will reword, which madnesse
Would gambole from. Mother for loue of grace,
Lay not that flattering vnction to your soule
That not your trespasse but my madnesse speakes,
It will but skin and filme the vlcerous place,
Whiles rancke corruption mining all within
Infects vnseene: confesse your selfe to heauen,
Repent what's past, auoyd what is to come,
And doe not spread the compost on the weedes
To make them rancker, forgiue me this my vertue,
For in the fatnesse of these pursie times
Vertue it selfe of vice must pardon beg,
Yea curbe and wooe for leaue to doe him good.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O Hamlet! thou hast cleft my hart in twaine.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O throw away the worser part of it,
And leaue the purer with the other halfe,
Good night, but goe not to my Vncles bed,
Assume a vertue if you haue it not,
That monster custome, who all sence doth eate
Of habits deuill, is angell yet in this
That to the vse of actions faire and good,
He likewise giues a frocke of Liuery
That aptly is put on to refraine night,
And that shall lend a kind of easines
To the next abstinence, the next more easie:
For vse almost can change the stamp of nature,
And Maister the diuell, or throw him out
With wonderous potency: once more good night,
And when you are desirous to be blest,
Ile blessing beg of you, for this same Lord
I doe repent; but heauen hath pleas'd it so
To punish me with this, and this with me,
That I must be their scourge and minister,
I will bestow him and will answer well
The death I gaue him; so againe good night
I must be cruell onely to be kinde,
This bad beginnes, and worse remaines behind.
One word more good Lady

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What shall I doe?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Not this by no meanes that I bid you doe,
Let the blowt King temp't you againe to bed,
Pinch wanton on your cheeke, call you his Mouse,
And let him for a paire of reechy kisses,
Or padling in your necke with his damn'd fingers.
Make you to rouell all this matter out
That I essentially am not in madnesse,
But mad in craft, t'were good you let him know.
For who that's but a Queene, faire, sober, wise,
Would from a paddack, from a bat, a gib,
Such deare concernings hide, who would doe so,
No, in dispight of sence and secrecy,
Vnpeg the basket on the houses top,
Let the birds fly, and like the famous Ape,
To try conclusions in the basket creepe,
And breake your owne necke downe.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Be thou assur'd, if words be made of breath,
And breath of life, I haue no life to breath
What thou hast sayd to me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I must to England, you know that,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Alacke I had forgot.
Tis so concluded on.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Ther's letters seald, and my two Schoolefellowes,
Whom I will trust as I will Adders fang'd,
They beare the mandat, they must sweepe my way
And marshall me to knauery: let it worke,
For tis the sport to haue the enginer
Hoist with his owne petar, an't shall goe hard
But I will delue one yard belowe their mines,
And blow them at the Moone: O tis most sweete
When in one line two crafts directly meete,
This man shall set me packing,
Ile lugge the guts into the neighbour roome;
Mother good night indeed, this Counsayler
Is now most still, most secret, and most graue,
Who was in life a most foolish prating knaue.
Come sir, to draw toward an end with you.
Good night mother.Exit.

div2.stage:
Enter King, and Queene, with Rosencraus
and Gyldensterne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: There's matter in thesesighes, these profoud heaues,
You must translate, tis fit we vnderstand them,
Where is your sonne?

sp.speaker: Gert.
sp.l: Bestow this place on vs a little while.
Ah mine owne Lord, what haue I seene to night?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What Gertrad, how dooes Hamlet?

sp.speaker: Gert.
sp.l: Mad as the sea and wind when both contend
Which is the mightier in his lawlesse fit,
Behind the Arras hearing some thing stirre,
Whips out his Rapier, cryis a Rat, a Rat,
And in this brainish apprehension kills
The vnseene good old man.

sp.speaker: King,
sp.l: O heauy deed!
It had beene so with vs had we beene there,
His liberty is full of threates to all,
To you your selfe, to vs, to euery one,
Alas, how shall this bloody deede be answer'd?
It will be layd to vs, whose prouidence
Should haue kept short, restraind, and out of haunt
This mad young man; but so much was our loue,
We would not vnderstand what was most fit,
But like the owner of a foule disease
To keepe it from divulging, let it feede
Euen on the pith of life: where is he gone?

sp.speaker: Gert.
sp.l: To draw apart the body he hath kild,
Ore whom, his very madnesse like some ore
Among a minerall of mettals base,
Showes it selfe pure, a weepes for what is done

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Gertrad, com away,
The Sunne no sooner shall the mountaines touch,
But wee will shippe him hence, and this vile deede
Wee must with all our Maiesty and skillEnter Ros. & Guyld.,
Both countenance and excuse. Ho Guyldensterne,
Friends both, goe ioyne you with some further ayde,
Hamlet in madnes hath Polonius slaine,
And from his mothers closset hath hee drag'd him,
Goe seeke him out speake sayre and bring the body
Into the Chappell; I pray you hast in this,
Come Gertrard, wee'le call vp our wisest friends,
And let them know both what wee meane to do
And whats vntimely done,
Whose whisper ore the worlds Diameter,
As leuell as the Cannon to his blanck,
Transports his poysned shot, may misse our name,
And hit the woundlesse ayre, O come away,
My soule is full of discord and dismay.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Safely stowd, but softly, what noyse, who calls on Hamlet?
O heere they come.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What haue you done my Lord with the dead body?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Compounded it with dust whereto it is kin.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Tell vs where tis that wee may take it thence,
And beare it to the Chappell.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Do not beleeue it.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Beleeue what?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
That I can keepe your counsaile and not mine owne, besides
to be demaunded of a spunge, what replication should be made by
the sonne of a King.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Take you me for a spunge my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I sir, that sokes vp the Kings countenance, his rewards, his
authorities, but such Officers do the King best seruice in the end, he
keepes them like an apple in the corner of his iaw, first mouth'd to be
last swallowed, when he needs what you haue gleand, it is but squee­
sing you, and spunge you shall be dry againe.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I vnderstand you not my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I am glad of it, a knauish speech sleepes in a foolish eare.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l:
My Lord, you must tell vs where the body is, and go with vs
to the King,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
The body is with the King, but the King is not with the
body. The King is a thing.

sp.speaker: Guyl.
sp.l: A thing my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Of nothing, bring me to him.Exeunt.

div2.stage: Enter King, and two or three.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I haue sent to seeke him, and to find the body,
How dangerous is it that this man goes loose,
Yet must not we put the strong Law on him,
Hee's lou'd of the ditracted multitude,
Who like not in their iudgement, but their eyes,
And where tis so, th'offenders scourge is wayed
But neuer the offence: to beare all smooth and euen,
This suddaine sending him away must seeme
Deliberate pause, diseases desperate growne,
By desperate applyance are relieu'd
Or not at all.

div2.stage: Enter Rosencraus and all the rest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How now, what hath befalne?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Where the dead body is bestowd my Lord
We cannot get from him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But where is he?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Without my Lord, guarded to know your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Kidg.
sp.l: Bring him before vs.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Hoe, bring in the Lord.They Enter.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now Hamlet, where's Polonius?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: At supper.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: At supper where.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Not where he eates, but where a is eaten, a certaine conua­
cation of politique wormes are een at him: your worme is your only
Emperour for dyet, we fat all creatures else to fat vs, and we fat our
selues for maggots, your fat King and your leane begger is but varia­
ble seruice, two dishes but to one table, that's the end.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Alasse, alasse.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
A man may fish with the worme that hath eate of a King,
eate of the fish that hath fedde of that worme.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What dost thou meane by this?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nothing but to shew you how a King may go a progresse
through the guttes of a begger.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where is Polonius?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
In heauen, send thether to see, if your messenger find him
not there, seeke him i'th other place your selfe, but if indeed you find
him not within this month, you shall nose him as you goe vppe the
stayres into the Lobby.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Goe seeke him there

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: A will stay till you come.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hamlet this deede for thine especiall safety
Which wee do tender, as wee deerely greeue
For that which thou hast done, must send thee hence:
Therefore prepare thy selfe,
The barke is ready, and the wind at helpe,
Th'assotiats tend, and euery thing is bent
For England.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: For England

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So is it if thou knew'st our purposes.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I see a Cherub that sees them, but come for England.
Farewell deere mother.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy louing father Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: My mother, father and mother is man and wife,
Man and wife is one flesh, so my mother:
Come for England,Exit–

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Follow him at foote,
Tempt him with speede abourd,
Delay it not, Ile haue him hence to night.
Away, for euery thing is seald and done
That els leanes on the affaire, pray you make hast,
And England if my loue thou hold'st at ought,
As my great power thereof may giue thee sence,
Since yet thy Cicatrice lookes raw and red,
After the Danish sword, and thy freee awe
Payes homage to vs, thou maist not coldly set
Our soueraigne processe, which imports at full
By letters congruing to that effect
The present death of Hamlet, do it England,
For like the Hectique in my blood hee rages,
And thou must cure me till I know tis done,
How ere my haps, my ioyes will nere beginne.Exit.

div2.stage: Enter Fortinbrasse with his Armie ouer the Stage.

sp.speaker: Fortin.
sp.l: Goe Captaine, from mee geet the Danish King,
Tell him, that by his lycence Fortinbrasse
Craues the conueyance of a promis'd march
Ouer his kingdome, you know the rendezuous,
If that his maiesty would ought with vs,
Wee shall expresse our duty in his eye,
And let him know so.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I will doo't my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fortin.
sp.l: Goe softly on.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Good sir whose powers are these?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: The are of Norway sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How proposd sir I pray you?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Aainst some part of Poland.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Who commands them sir?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: The Nephew to old Norway, Fortinbrasse.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Goes it against the maine of Poland sir?
Or for some frontire?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Truely to speake, and with no addition
We goe to gaine a little patch of ground
That hath in it no profit but the name
To pay fiue duckets, fiue I would not farme it?
Nor will it yeeld to Norway or the Pole
A rancker rate, should it bee sould in fee.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why then the Pollacke neuer will defend it.

sp.speaker: Cap
sp.l: Yes it is already garisond.

sp.speaker: Ham–
sp.l: Two thousand soules and twenty thousand duckets
Will not debate the question of this straw,
This is th'impostume of much wealth and peace,
That inward breakes and shewes no cause w ithout
Why the man dies. I humbly thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: God buy you sir.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Wil't please you goe my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Ile be with you straight, goe a little before.
How all occasions do informe against mee,
And spur my dull reuenge. What is a man
If his chiefe good and market of his time
Be but to sleepe and feed, a beast, no more:
Sure he that made vs with suh large discourse
Looking before and after, gaue vs not
That capability and God‐like reason
To fust in vs vnusd, now whether it be
Bestiall obliuion, or some crauen scruple
Of thinking too precisely on th'euent,
A thought which quartered hath but one part wisdome,
And euer three parts coward, I doe not know
Why yet I liue to say this thing's to doe,
Sith I haue cause, and wil and strength, and meanes
To doo't; examples grosse as earth exhort me,
Witnes this Army of such masse and charge,
Led by a delicate and tender Prince,
Whose spirit with diuine ambition puft,
Makes mouthes at the inuisible euent,
Exposing what is mortall, and vnsure,
To all that fortune, death and danger dare,
Euen for an Egge‐shell. Rightly to be great,
Is not to stirre without great argument,
But greatly to find quarrell in a straw
When honour's at the stake. How stand I then
That haue a father kild, a mother staind,
Excytements of my reason, and my blood,
And let all sleepe, while to my shame I see
The iminent death of twenty thousand men,
That for a fantasie and tricke of fame
Goe to their graues like beds, fight for a plot
Whereon the numbers cannot try the cause,
Which is not tombe enough and continent
To hide the slaine. O from this time forth,
My thoughts be bloody, or be nothing worth.Exit.

div2.stage: Enter Horatio, Gertrard, and a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I will not speake with her,

sp.speaker: Gsn.
sp.l: She is importunat,
Indeed distract, her moode will needes be pittied.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: What would she haue?

sp.speaker: Gent.,
sp.l: She speakes much of hcr father, sayes shee heares
There's tricks i'th world, and hems, and beats her heart,
Spurnes enuiously at strawes, speakes things in doubt
That carry but halfe sence, her speech is nothing,
Yet the vnshaped vse of it doth moue
The hearers to collection, they yawne at it,
And botch the words vp fit to their owne thoughts,
Which as winckes, and nods, and gestures yeeld them,
Indeede would make one thinke there might be thought
Though nothing sure, yet much vnhappily.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Twere good she were spoken with, for she may strew
Dangerous coniectures in ill‐breeeding mindes,
Let her come in

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: ‘To my sicke soule, as sinnes true nature is,
‘Each toy seemes prologue to some great amisse,
‘So full of artlesse iealosie is guilt,
‘It spills it selfe, in fearing to be spilt.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.l: Where is the beauteous Maiesty of Denmarke?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: How now Ophelia.she sings.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.l: How should I your true loue know from another one,
By his cockle hat and staffe, and his Sendall shoone.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Alasse sweet Lady, what imports this song?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.l: Say you, nay pray you make,
He is dead and gone Lady, he is dead and gone,Song.
At his head a grasse greene turph, at his heeles a stone.
O ho.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Nay but Ophelia.

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.l: Pray you marke. White his shrowd as the mountaine snow.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Alasse looke heere my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ophe
sp.l: Larded all with sweet flowers,
Which beweept to the ground did not goSong.
With true loue showers.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How doe you pretty Lady?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.l:
Well good dild you, they say the Owle was a Bakers daugh­
ter, Lord wee know what wee are, but know not what we may be,
God be at your table

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Conceit vpon her Father.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l:
Pray lets haue no words of this, but when they aske yo
what it meanes, say you this.
To morrow is S. Valentines day,Song.
All in the morning betime,
And I a mayd at your window
To be your Valentine.
Then vp he rose, and dond his close, and dupt the chamber doore,
Let in the maide, that out a maide, neuer departed more.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pretty Ophelia.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: Indeed without an oath Ile make an end on't,

By gis and by Saint charity,
alacke and fie for shame,

Young men will doo't if they come too't,
by Cocke they are too blame.
Quoth she, before you tumbled me, you promisd me to wed,
(He answers) So should I a done by yonder sunne
And thou hadst not come to my bed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How long hath she beene thus?

sp.speaker: Oph.
sp.p:
I hope all will be well, we must be patient, but I cannot chuse
but weepe to thinke they would lay him i'th cold ground my bro­
ther shall know of it, and so I thanke you for your good counsaile.
sp.l: Come my Coach, God night Ladies, God night.
Sweet Laides God night, God night.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Follow her elose, giue her good watch I pray you.

O this is the poyson of deepe griefe, it springs all from her Fathers
death, and now behold, O Gertrard, Gertrard,
When sorrowes come, they come not single spies,
But in battalians: first her Father slaine,
Next, your sonne gone, and he most violent Author
Of his owne iust remoue, the people muddied
Thick and vnwholesome in thoughts, and whispers
For good Polonius death: and we haue done but greenly
In hugger mugger to inter him: poore Ophelia
Deuided from herselfe, and her faire iudgement,
Without the which we are pictures, or meere beasts,
Last, and as much contayning as all these,
Her brother is in secret come from France,
Feeds on this wonder, keepes himselfe in clowdes,
And wants not buzzers to infect his eare
With pestilent speeches of his fathers death,
Wherein necessity of matter beggerd,
Will nothing stick our person to arraigne
In eare and eare: O my deare Gertrard, this
Like to a murdring‐peece in many places
Giues me superfluous death.A noyse within.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Attend, where are my Swissers, let them guard the doore,
What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: Saue your selfe my Lord.
The Ocean ouer‐peering of his list.
Eates not the flats with more impetuous ast
Then young Laertes in a riotous head
Ore‐beares your Officers: the rabble call him Lord,
And as the world were now but to beginne,
Antiquity forgot, custome not knowne,
The ratifiers and props of euery word,
The cry choose we, Laertes shall be King,
Caps, hands and tongues applau'd it to the clouds,
Laertes shall be King, Laertes King.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: How cheerefully on the false traile they cry.A noise within.
O this is counter, you false Danish dogges.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The doores are broke.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Where is this King? sirs stand you all without.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: No lets come in.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I pray you giue mee leaue.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We will, we will.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I thanke you: keepe the doore, O thou vile King,
Giue me my father.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Calmely good Laertes.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: That drop of blood thats calme proclaimes me Bastard,
Cries cuckold to my father, brands the Harlot
Euen heere betweene the chast vnsmerched browe
Of my true mother.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What is the cause Laertes
That thy rebellion lookes so Giant‐like?
Let him goe Gertrard, do not feare our person,
There's such diuinity doth hedge a King,
That treason cannot peepe to what it would,
Act's little of his will, tell me Laertes
Why thou art thus incenst, let him goe Gertrard,
Speake man.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Where is my father?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dead.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: But not by him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let him demaund his fill.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: How came he dead? Ile not be iugled with,
To hell alegiance, vowes to the blackest diuell,
Conscience and grace, to the profoundest pit
I dare damnation, to this poynt I stand,
That both the worlds I giue to negligence,
Let come what comes, onely Ile be reuengd
Most throughly for my father.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Who shall stay you?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: My will, not all the worlds:
And for my meanes Ile husband them so well,
The shall goe farre with little.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Good Laertes, if you desire to know the certainty
Of your deere father, i'st writ in your reuenge,
That soope‐stake, you will draw both friend and foe
Winner and looser.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: None but his enemies.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Will you know them then?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: To his good friends thus wide I'le ope my armes,
And like the kind life‐rendering Pelican,
Repast them with my blood.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why now you speake
Like a good child and a true Gentleman.
That I am guiltlesse of your fathers death,
And am most sencible in griefe for it,
It shall as leuell to your iudgement peare
As day dooes to your eye. A noyse within.

sp.speaker: Lae.
sp.l: Let her come in.
How now what noyse is that?
O heate, dry vp my braines, tear es seauen times salt
Burne out the sence and vertue of mine eye.
By heauen thy madnes shall be payd with weight
Till our scale turne the beame. O Rose of May,
Deere mayd, kind sister, sweet Ophelia,
O heauens, ist possible a young maids wits
Should be as mortall as a poore mans lif!

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: They bore him bare‐fac'd on the Beere,Song.
And in his graue rain'd many a teare,
Fare you well my Doue.

sp.speaker: .Laer.
sp.l: Hadst thou thy wits; and did'st perswade reuenge
It could not mooue thus.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: You must sing a downe a downe,
And you call him a downe a. O how the wheele becomes it,
It is the false Steward that stole his Maisters daughter,

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: This nothing's more then matter.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p:
There's Rosemary, that for remembrance, pray you loue re­
member, and there is Pancies, thats for thoughts.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: A document in madnes, thoughts and remembrance fitted.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.p:
There's Fennill for you, and Colembines, there's Rewe for
you, & heere's some for me, we may call it herbe of Grace a Sondaies,
you may weare your Rewe with a difference, there's a Dasie, I would
giue you some Violets, but they witherd all when my Father dyed,
they say a made a good end.
sp.l: For bonny sweet Robin is all my ioy.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Thought and afflictions, passion, hell it selfe
She turnes to fauour and to prettinesse.

sp.speaker: Ophe.
sp.l: And will a not come againe,Song.
And will a not come againe,
No, no, he is dead, goe to thy death bed,
He neuer will come againe.
His beard was as white as snow,
Flaxen was his pole,
He is gone, he is gone, and we cast away mone,
God a mercy on his soule, and all Christians soules,
God buy yous.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Doe you this O God.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Laertes, I must commune with your griefe,
Or you deney me right, goe but a part,
Make choice of whome your wisest friends you will,
And they shall heare and iudge twixt you and me,
If by direct or by colaturall hand
They find vs toucht, we will our kindome giue,
Our crowne, our life, and all that we call ours
To you in satisfaction; but if not,
Be you content to lend your patience to vs,
And we shall ioyntly labour with your soule
To giue it due content.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Let this be so.
His meanes of death, his obscure funeall,
No trophæ, sword, nor hachment ore his bones,
No noble right, nor formall ostentation,
Cry to be heard as twere from heauen to earth,
That I must call't in question.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: So you shall,
And where th'Offence is, let the great axe fall.
I pray you goe with me.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What are they that would speake with me?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Sea‐faring men sir, they say they haue Letters for you.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Let them come in.
I doe not know from what part of the world
I should be greeted. If not from Lord Hamlet.Enter Saylers

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: God blesse you sir.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Let him blesse thee to.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p:
A shall sir and please him, there's a Letter for you sir, it came
from th'Embassador that was bound for England, if your name bee
Horatio, as I am let to know it is.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p:
Horatio, when thou shalt haue ouer‐look't this, giue these fel­
lowes some meanes to the King, they haue Letters for him: Ere wee
were two daies old at Sea, a Pyrat of very warlike appointment gaue
vs chase, finding our selues too slow of saile, we put on a compelled
valour, and in the grapple I boorded them, on the instant they got
cleere of our ship, so I alone became their prisoner, they haue dealt
with me like theeues of mercy, but they knew what they did: I am to
doe a turne for them, let the King haue the Letters I haue sent, and
repayre thou to mee with as much speed as thou wouldst fly death.
I haue words to speake in thine eare wil make thee dumbe, yet are they
Prince of Denmarke. they mueh too light for the bord of the matter, these good fellowes
will bring thee where I am, Rosencraus and Guildersterne hold their
course for England, of them I haue much to tell thee, farwell.

p.hi: So that thou knowest thine Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Come I will make you way for these your letters,
And doo't the speedier that you may direct me
To him from whome you brought them.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now must y our conscience my acquittance seale,
And you must put me in your heart for friend,
Sith you haue heard and with a knowing eare,
That he which hath your noble father slaie
Pursued my life.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: It well appeares: but tell me
Why you proceede not against these eates
So criminall and so capitall in nature,
As by your safety, greatnes, wisdome, all things els,
You mainly were stirr'd vp.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O for two speciall reasons
Which may to you perhaps seeme much vnsinnow'd,
But yet to me tha'r strong, the Queene his mother
Liues almost by his lookes, and for my selfe,
My vertue or my plague, be it either which,
She is so concliue to my life and soule,
That as the starre mooues not but in his sphere
I could not but by her, the other motiue,
Why to a publique count I might not goe,
Is the great loue the generall gender beare him,
Who dipping all his faults in their affection,
Worke like the spring that turneth wood to stone,
Conuert his Giues to graces, so that my arrowes
Too slightly tymbered for so loued armes,
Would haue reuerted to my bow againe,
But not where I haue aym'd them.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: And so haue I a noble father lost,
A sister driuen into desperat termes,
VVhose worth, if prayses may goe backe againe
Stood challenger on mount of all the age
For her perfections, but my reuenge will come.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Breake not your sleepes for that, you must not thinke
That we are made of stuffe so flat and dull,
That we can let our berd be shooke with danger,
And thinke it pastime, you shortly shall heare more,
I lou'd your father, and we loue our selfe,
And that I hope will teach you to imagine.

sp.speaker: Messe.
sp.l: These to your Maiesty, this to the Queene.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: FroHamlet, who brought them?

sp.speaker: Messe.
sp.l: Saylers my Lord they say, I saw them not,
They were giuen me by Claudio, he receiued them
Of him that brought them.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Laertes you shall heare them: leaue vs.
sp.p:
High and mighty, you shall know I am set naked on your kingdome,
to morrow shall I begge leaue to see your kingly eyes, when I shall,
first asking you pardon, there‐vnto recount the occasion of my sud­
daine returne.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What should this meane, are all the rest come backe,
Or is it some abuse, an no such thing?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Know you the hand?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tis Hamlets caracter. Naked,
And in a postscript here he saies alone,
Can you deuise me?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I am lost in it my Lord, but let him come,
It warmes the very sicknes in my heart
That I liue and tell him to his teeth,
Thus didst thou.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: If it be so Laertes,
As how should it be so, how otherwise,
Will you be rul'd by me?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I my Lord, so you will not ore‐rule me to a peace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To thine owne peace, if he be now returned,
As liking not his voyage, and that he meanes,
No more to vnder take it, I will worke him
To an exployt, now ripe in my deuise,
Vnder the which he shall not choose but fall:
And for his death no wind of blame shall breahe,
But euen his mother shall vncharge the practise,
And call it accedent.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: My Lord I will be rul'd,
The rather if you could deuise it so
That I might be the ogan.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It falls right,
You haue beene talkt of since your trauaile much,
And that in Hamlets hearing for a quality
Wherein they say you shine, your summe of parts
Did not together plucke such enuy from him
As did that one, and that in my regard
Of the vworthiest siedge.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: What part is that my Lotd?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A very riband in the cap of youth,
Yet needfull too, for youth no lesse becomes
The light and carelesse liuery that it weares
Then settled age, his sables, and his weedes
Importing health and grauenes; two monthes since
Heere was a Gcntleman of Normandy,
I haue seene my selfe, and seru'd against the French,
And they can well on horse‐backe, but this Gallant
Had witch‐craft in't, he grew vnto his seate,
And to such wondrous dooing brought his horse,
As had he beene incorp'st, and demy‐natur'd
With the braue beast, so farre he topt me thought,
That I in forgery of shapes and tricks
Come short of what he did.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: A Norman wast?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A Norman.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Vpon my life Lamord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I know him, well he is the brooch indeed
And Iem of all the Nation.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He made consession of you,
And gaue you such a maisterly report
For art and exerise in your defence,
And for your Rapier most especiall,
That he cryd out t'would be a sight indeed
If one could match you; the Scrimers of their nation
He swore had neither motion, guard, nor eye,
If you oppos'd them; sir this report of his
Did Hamlet so enuenom with his enuy,
That he could nothing do, but wish and beg
Your sodaine comming ore to play with you.
Now out of this.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: What out of this my Lord?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Laertes was your father, deere to you?
Or are you like the paintig of a sorrowe,
A face without a heart?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Why aske you this?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Not that I thinke you did not loue your father,
But that I know, loue is begunne by time,
And that I see in passages of proofe,
Time quallifies the sparke and fire of it,
There liues within the very flame of loue
A kind of weeke or snuffe that will abate it,
And nothing is at a like goodnes still,
For goodnes growing to a plurisie,
Dies in his owne too much, that we would doe
We should doe when wee would: for this would changes,
And hath abatements and delayes as many,
As there are tongues, are hands, are accedents,
And then this should is like a spend‐thrifts sigh,
That hurrs by easing; but to the quicke of th'vlcer,
Hamlet comes back what would you vndertake
To show your selfe indeed your fathers sonne
More then in words?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: To cut his throat i'th Church–

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No place indeede should murther sanctuarize,
Reuengde should haue no bounds: but good Laertes
Will you doe this, keepe close within your chamber
Hamlet return'd, shall know you are come home,
Weele put on those shall praise your excellence,
And set a double varnish on the fame
The french man gaue you: bring you in in fine ogether
And wager ore your heads; he being remisse,
Most generous, and free from all contriuing,
Will not peruse the foyles, so that with ease,
Or with a little shuffling, you may choose
A sword vnbated, and in a pace of practise,
Requite him for your Father.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I will doo't,
And for the purpose, Ile annoynt my sword.
I bought an vnction of a Mountibancke
So mortall, that but dippe a knife in it,
Where it drawes blood, no Cataplase so rare
Collected from all simples that haue vertue
Vnder the Moone, can saue the thing from death
That is but scratcht withall, Ile tutch my point
With this contagion, that if I gall him slightly, it may be death.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Lets further thinke of this.
Wey what conueiance both of time and meanes
May fit vs to our shape if this should fayle,
And that our drift looke through our bad performance,
Twere better not assayd. Therefore this proiect,
Should haue a backe or second that might hold
If this did blast in proofe; soft let me see,
Wee'le make a solemne wager on your cunnings,
I hau't, when in your motion you are hote and dry,
As make your bouts more violent to that end,
And that he calls for drinke, Ile haue preferd him
A Challice for the once, whereon but sipping,
If he by chance escape your venom'd stucke,
Our purpose may hold there; but stay, what noyse?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: One woe doth tread vpon anothers heele,
So fast they follow; your Sisters drownd Laertes.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Drown'd, O where?

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: There is a Willow growes ascaunt the Brooke,
That showes his hoary leaues in the glassy streame,
There with fantastique garlands did she make
Of Crowflowers, Nettles, Dasies, and long Purples
That liberall Shepheards giue a grosser name,
But our cull‐cold maydes doe dead mens fingers call them.
There on the pendant boughes her coronet weeds
Clambring to hang, an enuious sluer broke,
When downe her weedy trophæs and her selfe,
Fell in the weeping Brooke, her clothes spred wide,
And Mermaide‐like a while they bore her vp,
Which time she chaunted snatches of old laudes,
As one incapable of her owne distresse.
Or like a creature natiue and indewed
Vnto that element, but long it could not be
Till that her garments heauy with their drinke,
Puld the poore wench from her melodious lay
To muddy death.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Alas ten is she drownd.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Drownd, drownd.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: Too much of water hast thou poore Ophlia,
And therefore I forbid my teares; but yet
It is our tricke, nature her custome holds,
Let shame say what it will, when these are gone,
The woman will be out. Adiew my Lord,
I haue a speecha fire that fainewould blase,
But that this folly drownes itExit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let's follow Gertrard,
How much I had to doe to calme his rage,
Now eare I this will giue it start againe.
Therefore lets follow.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.p:
Is she to be buried in Christian buriall, when she wilfully
seekes her owne saluation?

sp.speaker: Othe.
sp.p:
I tell thee she is, therfore make her graue straight, the crow­
ner hath sate on her, and finds it Christian buriall.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
How can that be, vnlesse she drown'd herselfe in her owne
defence.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Why tis found so.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
It must be so offended, it cannot be else, for heere lyes the
poynt, if I drowne my selfe wittingly, it argues an act, and an act hath
three branches, it is to act, to doe, to performe, or all; she drownd her
selfe wittingly.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Nay, but heare you good man deluer.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Giue me leaue, here lies the water, good, here stands the man,
Prince of Denmarke. man, good, if the man goe to this water & drowne himselfe, it is will
he, nill he, he goes, marke you that, but if the water come to him, and
drowne him, he drownes not himselfe, argall, he that is not guilty of
his owne death. shortens not his owne life.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: But is this law?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I marry i'st, Crowners quest law.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p:
Will you ha the truth an't, if this had not beene a gentlewo­
man, she should haue bin burid out a Christian buriall.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Why there thou sayst, and the more pitty that great folke
should haue countenance in this world to drown or hang themselues,
more then their euen Christen: Come my spade, there is no aunci­
ent gentlemen but Gardners, Ditchers, and Graue‐makers, they hold
vp Adams profession.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Was he a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
A was the first that euer bore armes.
Ile put another question to thee, if thou answerest me not to the pur­
pose, confesse thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Goe to.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
what is he that builds stronger then either the Mason, the
Shipwright, or the Carpenter.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: the gallowes‐maker, for that out‐liues a thousand tennants.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
I like thy wit well in good faith, the gallowes dooes well,
but how dooes it well? It dooes well to those that do ill, now thou
doost ill to say the gallowes is built stronger then the Church, argal,
the gallowes may doe well to thee. Too't againe, come.

sp.speaker: Other.
sp.p:
Who buildes stronger then a Mason, a Shipwright, or a
Carpenter.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I, tell me that and vnyoke.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Marry now I can tell.

sp.speaker: Oth.
sp.p: Too't.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Masse I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Cudgell thy braines no more about it, for your dull asse will
not mend his pace with beating, and when you are askt this question
next, say a graue‐maker, the houses he makes last tell Doomesday.
Goe get thee in and fetch me a soope of liquer.
sp.l: In youth when I did loue did loue,Song.
Me thought it was very sweet
To contract O the time for a my behoue,
O me thought there a was nothing a meet.

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.p:
Has this fellow no feeling of his busines? a sings in graue­
making

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Custome hath made it in him a property of easines.

sp.speaker: Ha,
sp.p: Tis een so, the hand of little imploiment hath the daintier sence

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: But age with his stealing steppesSong.
hath clawed mee in his clutch,

And hath shipped me into the land,
as if I had neuer beene such.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
That skull had a tongue in it, and could sing once, how the
knaue iowles it to the ground, as if twere Caines iaw‐bone, that did
the first murder: this might be yͤ pate of a polliticiāpollitician, which this Asse
now ore‐reaches. one that would circumuent God, might it not?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: It might my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Or of a Courtier, which could say good morrow my Lord:
how dost thou sweet Lord? This might be my Lord such a one, that
praised my lord such a ones horse whēwhen a ment to beg it: might it not?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Why een so, & now my Lady wormes Choples, & knockt
about the maz er with a Sextens spade; heer's fine reuolution and
we had the trick to see't, did these bones cost no more the breeding,
but to play at loggits with them: mine ake to thinke ont.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: A pickax and a spade a spade,Song.
for and a shrowding sheet,

O a pit of Clay for to be made
for such a guest is meet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
There's another, why may not that be the skull of a lawyer?
where be his quiddities now, his quillities, his cases, his tenurs, & his
trickes? why dooes he suffer this mad knaue now to knock him a­
bout the sconce with a durty shouell, and will not tell him of his acti­
on of battery: hum, this fellow might be in's time a great buyer of
Land, with his Statutes, his recognisances, his fines, his double vou­
chers, his recoueries, to haue his fine pate full of fine durt: will vou­
chers vouch him no more of his purchases & doubles then the length
and breadth of a payre of Indentures? The vety conueyances of his
Lands will scarcely lye in this box, and must th'inheritor himselfe
haue no more? ha.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Not a iot more my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Is not parchment made of sheepe‐skinnes?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: I my Lord, and of Calue‐skinnes too.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
They are Sheepe and Calues which seeke out assurance in
that, I will speake to this fellow. Whose graue's this sirra?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Mine sir, or a pit of clay for to be made.

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.p: I thinke it be thine indeede for thou lyest in't.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
You lye out ont sir, and therefore tis not yours; for my part
I doe not lye in't, yet it is mine.

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.p:
Thou dost lye in't to be in't and say it is thine, tis for the
dead, not for the quicke, therefore thou lyest.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Tis a quicke lye sir, twill away againe from me to you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What man dost thou digge it for?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: For no man sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What woman then?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: For none neither.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Who is to be buried in't?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: One that was a woman sir, but rest her soule shee's dead.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
How absolute the knaue is, we must speake by the card, or
equiuocation will vndoo vs. By the Lord Horatio, this three yeares I
haue tooke note of it, the age is growne so picked, that the toe of the
pesant comes so neere the heele of the Courtier he galls his kybe.
How long hast thou bene a Graue‐maker?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Of the dayes i'th yeare I came too't that day that our last
King Hamlet ouercame Fortinbrasse.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How long is that since?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Cannot you tell that? euery foole can tell that, it was that
very day that young Hamlet was borne: he that is mad and sent into
England.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: I marry why was he sent into England?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Why because a was mad: a shall recouer his wits there, or if
a doe not, tis no great matter there,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Twill not be seene in him there, there the are men as mad
(as hee.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How came he mad?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Very strangely they say,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How strangely?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Faith eene with loosing his wits.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Vpon what ground?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Why heere in Denmarke: I haue beene Sexton heere man
and boy thirty yeares.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: How long will a man lie i'th earth ere he ro?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Faith if a be not rotten before a die, as we haue many po­
kie corses, that will scarce hold the laying in, a will last you some
eight yeare, or nine yeare. A Tanner will last you nine yeare,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Why he more then another?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Why sir, his hide is so tand with his trade, that a will keepe
out water a great while; & your water is a sore decayer of your whor­
son dead body, heer's a scull now hath lyen you i'th earth 23. yeares.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Whose was it?

sp.speaker: Clow,
sp.p: A whorson mad fellowes it was, whose do you think it was?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Nay I know not.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
A pestilence on him for a mad rogue, a pourd a flagon of
Renish on my head once; this same skull sir, was sir Yoricks skull, the
Kings Iester.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: This?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Een that.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Alas poore Yoricke, I knew him Horatio, a fellow of infinite
iest, of most excelent fancy, hee hath bore me on his backe a thou­
sand times, and now how abhorred in my imagination it is: my gorge
rises at it. Here hung those lyppes that I haue kist I know not how
oft: where be your gibes now? your gamboles, your songs, your fla­
shes of merriment, that were wont to set the table on a roare, not one
now to mocke your owne grinning, quite chopflne. Now get you
to my Ladies table, and tell her, let her paint an inch thicke, to this fa­
uour she must come, make her laugh at that.
Prethee Horatio tell me one thing.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: What's that my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: Doost thou thinke Alexander lookt a this fashon i'th earth?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Een so.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: And smelt so: pah.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Een so my Lord

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
To what base vses we may returne Horatio? Why may not
imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander, till a find it stopping
a bunghole?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Twere to consider too curiously to consider so.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
No faith, not a iot, but to follow him thether with modesty
enough, and likelihood to leade it. Alexander died, Alexander was
buried, Alexander returneth to dust, the dust is earth, of earth wee
make Lome, & why of that Lome whereto he was conuerted, might
sp.l: They not stoppe a Beare‐barrell?
Imperious Cæsar dead, and turn'd to Clay,
Might stoppe a hole, to keepe the wind away.
O that that earth which kept the world in awe,
Should patch a wall t'expell the waters flaw.

But soft, but soft awhile, here comes the King,Enter King
Quee. Laertes
and the corse.
The Queene, the courtiers, who is this they follow?
And with such maimed rites? this doth betoken,
The corse they follow, did with desprat hand
Foredoo it owne life, twas of some estate,
Couch we a while and marke.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: What Ceremony else?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: That is Laertes a very noble youth, make.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: What Ceremony else?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Her obsequies haue beene as farre inlarg'd
As we haue warranty, her death was doubtfull,
