And but that great command ore‐swayes the order,
She should in ground vnsanctified beene lodg'd
Till the last trumpet: for charitable prayers,
Flints and peebles should be throwne on her:
Yet heere she is allow'd her virgin Crants,
Her mayden strewments, and the bringing home
Of bell and buriall.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Must there no more be doone?

sp.speaker: Doct
sp.l: No more be doone.
We should prophane the seruice of the dead,
To sing a Requiem and such rest to her
As to peace‐parted soules.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Lay her i'th earth,
And from her faire and vnpolluted flesh
May Violets spring: I tell thee churlish Priest,
A ministring Angell shall my sister be
When thou lyest howling.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What, the faire Ophelia.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Sweets to the sweet, farewell,
I hop't thou should'st haue beene my Hamlets wife,
I thought thy bride‐bed to haue deckt sweet maide,
And not haue strew'd thy graue.

sp.speaker: aer.
sp.l: O trebble woe
Fall tenne times double on that cursed head.
Whose wicked deede thy most ingenious sence
Depriued thee of, hold off the earth a while,
Till I haue caught her once more in mine armes;
Now pile your dust vpon the quicke and dead,
Till of this flat a mountaine you haue made
To'retop old Pelion, or the skyesh head
Of blew Olympus.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What is he whose griefe
Beares such an Emphasis, whose phrase of sorrow
Coniures the wandring starres, and makes them stand
Like wonder wounded hearers? tis I
Hamlet the Dane.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: The Diuell take thy soule,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
Thou pray'st not well, I prethee take thy fingers
(from my throat,
For though I am not spleenatiue rash,
Yet haue I in me something dangerous,
Which let thy wisedome feare; hold off thy hand?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Plucke them a sunder.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Hamlet, Hamlet.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: ora.
sp.l: Good my Lord be quiet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why, I will fight with him vpon this theame
Vntill my eye‐lids will no longer wagge.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: O my sonne, what theame?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I lou'd Ophelia: forty thousand brothers
Could not with all their quantity of loue
Make vp my summe. What wilt thou doo for her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O he is mad Laertes.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: For loue of God forbeare him?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: S'wounds shew me what th'out doe:
Woo't weepe, woo't fight, woo't fast, woo't teare thy selfe,
Woo't drinke vp Esill, eate a Crocadile
Ile doo't: doost come heere to whine?
To out‐face me with leaping in her graue,
Be buried quicke with her, and so will I.
And if thou prate of mountaines, let them throw
Millions of Aeres on vs, till our ground
Sindging his pate against the burning Zone
Make Ossa like a wart, nay and thou'lt mouth,
Ile rant as well as thou.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: This is meere madnesse,
And this a while the fit will worke on him,
Anon as patient as the female Doe
When that her golden cuplets are disclosed
His silence will sit drooping.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Heare you sir,
What is the reason that you vse me thus?
I lou'd you euer, but it is no matter,
Let Hercules himselfe doe what he may

The Cat will mew, a dogge will haue his day.Exit Hamlet,
and Horatio.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I pray thee good oratio waite vpon him.
Strengthen your patience in our last nights speech,
Weele put the matter to the present push:
Good Gertrard set some watch ouer your sonn,
This graue shall haue a liuing monument,
An houre of quiet thereby shall we see
Tell then in patience our proceeding be.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: So much for this sir, now shall you see the other,
You doe remember all the circumstance.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Remember it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Sir in my heart there was a kind of fighting
That would not let me sleepe, me thought I lay
Worse then the mutines in the bilbo's, rashly,
And praysd be rashnes for it: let vs know,
Our indiscretion sometime serues vs well
When our deepe plots doe fall, and that should learne vs
Ther's a diuinity hat shapes our ends,
Rough hew them how we will.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: That is most certaine.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Vp from my Cabin,
My sea‐gowne scarft about me in the darke
Gropt I to find out them, had my desire,
Fingard their packet, and in fine with‐drew
To mine owne roome againe, making so bold
My feares forgetting manners to vnfold
Their graund commission; where I found Horatio
A royall knauery, an exact command
Larded with many seuerall sorts of reasons,
Importing Denmarkes health, and Englands to,
With hoe such bugges and goblins in my life,
That on the superuise no leasure bated,
No not to stay the grinding of the Axe,
My head should be strooke off.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I'st possible?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Heeres the commmission, read it at more leasure,
But wilt thou heare now how I did proceed.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Being thus be‐netted round with villaines,
Or I could make a prologue to my braines,
They had begunne the play, I sat me downe,
Deuisd a new commission, wrote it faire,
I once did hold it as our statists doe
A basenesse to write faire, and labourd much
How to forget that learning, but sir now
It did me yemans seruice, wilt thou know
Th' effect of what I wrote?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: An earnest coniuration from the King,
As England was his faithfull tributary,
As loue betweene them like the palme might florish,
As peace should still her wheaten garland weare
And stand a Comma tweene their amities,
And many such like, as sir of great charge,
That on the view, and knowing of these contents,
Without debatement further more or lesse,
He should those bearers put to suddaine death,
Not shriuing time alow'd.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: How was this seald?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why euen in that was heauen ordinant,
I had my fathers signet in my purse
Which was the model of that Danish seale,
Folded the writ vp in the forme of th'other,
Subscrib'd it, gau't th'impression, plac'd it safely,
The changling neuer knowne: now the next day
Was our Sea‐fight, and what to this was sequent
Thou knowest already.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: So Guyldensterne and Rosencraus goe too't.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: They are not neere my conscience; their defeat
Dooes by their owne insinuation growe,
Tis dangerous when the baser nature comes
Betweene the passe and fell incenced poynts
Os mighty opposits.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Why what a King is this!

sp.speaker: Ham,
sp.l: Dooe it not thinke thee stand me now vppon?
Hee that hath kild my King, and whor'd my mother,
Pop't in betweene the election and my hopes,
Throwne out his Angle for my proper life,
And with such cosnage, i'st not perfect conscicnce?

sp.speaker: Cour,
sp.l: Your Lordshippe is right welcome backe to Denmarke,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I humbly thanke you sir.
Doo'st know this water‐fly?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: No my good Lord,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Thy state is the more gratious, for tis a vice to know him,
He hath much land and fertill: let a beast be Lord of beasts, and his
crib shall stand at the Kings messe, tis a chough, but as I say, spaci­
ous in the possession of durt.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p:
Sweet Lord, if your Lordshippe were at Leasure, I should
impart a thing to you from his Maiesty.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
I will receiue it sir with all dilligence of spirrit, your bonnet
to his right vse, tis for the head.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I thanke your Lordship, it is very hot.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No beleeue me, tis very cold, the wind is Northerly,

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: It is indifferent cold my Lord indeed,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
But yet me thinkes it is very soultry and hot, or my com­
plexion.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p:
Exceedingly my Lord, it is very soultry, as t'were I cannot
tell how: my Lord his Maiesty bad me signifie to you, that a has layed
a great wager on your head, sir this is the matter.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I beseech you remember.

sp.speaker: Cou
sp.p:
Nay good my Lord for my ease in good faith, sir here is newly
come to court Laertes, beleeue me an absolute gentlemāgentleman, full of most N2excellent
The Tragedy of Hamlet excellent differences, of very soft society, and great showing: in­
deede to speake feelingly of him, he is the card or kalender of Gent­
try: for you shall finde in him the continent of what part a Gentle­
man would see.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Sir, his definement suffers no perdition in you, though I
know to devide him inuentorially, would dizzie th'arithmeticke of
memory, and yet but raw neither, in respect of his quick saile, but
in the verity of extolment, I take him to be a soule of great article,
and his infusion of such dearth and rarenesse, us to make true dixion
of him, his semblable is his mirrour, and who els would trace him,
his vmbrage, nothing more.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Your Lordship speakes most infallibly of him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
The concernancy sir, why do wee wrap the Gentleman in
our more rawer breath?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l:
Ist not possible to vnderstand in another tongue, you will
doo't sir really.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What imports the nomination of this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Of Laertes.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: His purse is empty already, all's golden words are spent.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Of him sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I know you are not ignorant.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
I would you did sir, yet in fayth if you did, it would not
much approoue me, well sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: You are ignorant of what excellence Laertes is

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I dare not confesse that, least I should compare with him
in excellence, but to know a man well, were to know himselfe.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p:
I meane si for this weapon, but in the imputation layd on
him by them in his meed, hee's vnfellowed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What's his weapon?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Rapiar and Dagger.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: That's two of his weapons, but well.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p:
The King sir hath wagerd with him six Barbary horses a­
gainst the which he has impaund as I take it six french Rapiers and
Poynards, with their assignes, as girdle, hanger and so. Three of the
cariages in faith, are very deare to fancy, very responsiue to the hilts,
most dilicate carriages, and of very liberall conceit.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What call you the carriages?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l:
I knew you must be edified by the margent ere you had done.
Prince of Denmarke. done.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: The carriage sir are the hangers.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
The phrase would be more German to the matter if wee
could carry a Cannon by our sides, I would it might be hangers till
then, but on, six Barbary horses against six french swords their as­
signes, and three liberall conceited carriages, that's the French bet
against the Danish, why is this all you call it?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p:
The King sir, hath laid sir, that in a dozen passes betweene
your selfe and him, hee shall not exceede you three hits, hee hath
layd on twelue for nine, and it would come to immediate tryall, if
your Lordshippe would vouchsafe the answere.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How if I answere no?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I meane my Lord the opposition of your person in tryall.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Sir I will walke heere in the hall, If it please his Maiesty, it
is the breathing time of day with mee, let the foyles be brought, the
Gentleman willinge, and the Kinge hold his purpose; I will winne
for him and I can, if not I will gaine nothing but my shame, and the
odde hits.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Shall I deliuer you so?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: To this effect sir, after what florish your nature will.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I commend my duty to your Lordshippe.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
Yours doo's well to commend it himselfe, there are no
tongues es for's turne.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: This Lapwing runnes away with the shell on his head.

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.p:
A did so sir with his dugge before a suckt it, thus has he and
many more of the same beede that I know the drossy age dotes on,
onely got the tune of the time, and out of an habit of incounter, a
kind of misty collection, which carryes them through and through
the most prophane and trennowned opinions, and doe but blowe
them to their tryall, the bubbles are out

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
My Lord, his Maiesty commended him to you by younge
Ostricke, who brings backe to him that you attend him in the hall,
hee sends to know if your pleasure hold to play with Laertes, or that
you will take longer time?

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.p:
I am constant to my purposes, they follow the Kings plea­
sure, if his fitnes speakes, mine is ready: now or whensoeuer, pro­
uided I be so able as now.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: The King and Queene and all are comming downe.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: In happy time.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
The Queene desires you to vse some gentle entertainment
to Laertes, before you goe to play.

sp.speaker: Ham,
sp.l: Shee well instructs me,

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: You will loose my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
I doe not thinke so, since hee went into France, I haue bin
in continuall practise, I shall winne at the ods; thou would'st not
thinke how ill all's heere about my heart, but it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Nay good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham,
sp.p:
It is but foolery, but it is such a kinde of game‐giuing, as
would perhaps trouble a woman.

sp.speaker: Hora,
sp.p:
If your mind dislike any thing, obay it. I will forestall their
repaire hether and say you are not fit.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Not a whit we defie augury, there is speciall prouidence in
the fall of a Sparrowe, if i be, tis not to come, if it bee not to come,
it will be now, if it bee not now, yet it will come, the readines is all,
since no man of ought hee leaues, knowes what ist to leaue betimes,
let bee.

div2.stage:
A table prepard, Trumpets, Drums and Officers with Cushions,
King, Queene, and all the state Foiles, Daggers, and Laertes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come Hamlet, come and take this hand from me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Giue me your pardon sir, I haue done you wrong,
But pardon't as you are a Gentleman, this presence knowes,
And you must needs haue heard, how I am punisht
Wiih a sore distraction: what I haue done
That might your nature, honor. and exception
Roughly awake I heere proclaime was madnes,
Wast Hamlet wronged Laertes? neuer Hamlet.
If Hamlet from himselfe be tane away,
And when hee's not himselfe, doo's wrong Laertes,
Then Hamlet doo's it not, Hamlet denies it,
Who dooes it then? his madnes. Ift be so,
Hamlet is of the faction that is wronged,
His madnesse is poore Hamlets enemie,
Let my disclaiming from a purpos'd euill,
Free me so farre in your most generous thoughts
That I haue shot my arrowe ore the house
And hurt my brother.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I am satisfied in nature,
Whose motiue in this case should stirre me most
To my reuendge, but in my tearmes of honor
I stand a loofe, and will no reconcilement,
Till by some elder Maisters of knowne honor
I haue a voyce and president of peace
To my name vngor'd: but all that time
I doe reeiue your offerd loue, like loue,
And will not wrong it.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
I embace it freely, and will this brothers wager
franckly play.
Giue vs the foiles.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Come, one for me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Ile be your foile Laertes, in mine igorance
Your skill shall like a starre i'th darkest night
Stick fiery of indeed.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: You mocke me sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No by this hand.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Giue them the foiles young Ostricke, cosin Ham.
You know the wager,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Very well my Lord.
Your grace has layde the ods a'th weaker side.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I doe not feare it, I haue seene you both,
But since he is better, we haue therefore ods.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: This is to heauy: let me see another.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: This likes me well, these foiles haue all a length.

sp.speaker: Ostr.
sp.l: I my good Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Set me the stoopes of wine vpon the table,
If Hamlet giue the first or second hit,
Or quit in answer of the third exchange.
Let all the battlements their ordnance fire.
The King shall drinke to Hamlets better breath,
And in the cup an Onixe shall he throw,
Richer then that which foure successiue Kings
In Denmarkes Crowne haue worne: giue me the cups,
And let the kettle to the trumpet speake,
The trumpet to the Cannoneere without,
The Cannons to the heauens, the heauens to earth,

Mathematical formulas.Now the King drinkes to Hamlet, come beginne.Trumpets
the while.
And you the Iudges beare a wary eye.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Come on sir.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Come my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: One.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Iudgement.

sp.speaker: Ostr.
sp.l:
A hit, a very palpable hit.Drum, trumpets and shot.
Florish, a peece goes off.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Well, againe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stay, giue me drinke, Hamlet this pearle is thine.
Heeres to thy health, giue him the cup.

sp.speaker: Ham:
sp.l: Ile play this bout first, set it by a while
Come, another hit. What say you?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I doe confest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Our sonne shall winne.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Hee's fat and scant of breath.
Heere Hamlet take my napkin rub thy browes,
The Qeene carowses to thy fortune Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Good Madam.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Gertrard, doe not drinke.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I will my Lord, I pray you pardon me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It is the poysned cup, it is too late.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I dare not drinke yet Madam, by and by.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Come, let me wipe thy face.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: My Lord, Ile hit him now.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I doe not think't.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: And yet it is almost against my conscience,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Com for the third Laertes, you doe but dally.
I pray you passe with your best violence
I am sure you make a wanton of me.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Say you so come on.

sp.speaker: Ostr.
sp.l: Nothing neither way.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Haue at you now.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pat them, they are incenst.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay come againe.

sp.speaker: Ostr.
sp.l: Looke to the Queene there hoe.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: They bleed on both sides, how is it my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ostr.
sp.l: Host ist Laeres?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Why as a woodcock to mine owne sprindge. Ostrick
I am iustly kild with mine owne treachery.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How does the Queene?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: She sounds to see them bleed.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: No, no, the drink, the drinke, O my deare Ham
The drinke, the drinke, I am poysned.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O villanie! hoe let the dore be lock't,
Treachery, seeke it out.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: It is heere Hamlet, thou art slaine,
No medcin in the world can do thee good,
In thee there is not halfe an houres life,
The treacherous instrument is in my hand
Vnbated and enuenom'd, the foule practise
Hath turn'd it selfe on me, loe here I lye
Neuer to rise againe: thy mother's poysned,
I can no more, the King, the Kings too blame.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The point enuenom'd to, then venom to thy worke.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Treason, treason.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O yet defend me friends, I am but hurt.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Here thou incestious damned Dane,
Drinke of this potion, is the Onixe heere?
Follow my mother.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: He is iustly serued, it is a poyson temperd by himsefe.
Exchange forgiuenes with me noble Hamlet,
Mine and my fathers death come not vppon thee,
Nor thine on me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Heauen make thee free of it, I follow thee;
I am dead Horatio, wretched Queene adiew.
You that looke pale and tremble at this chance,
That are but mutes, or audience to this act,
Had I but time as this fell Sergeant Death
Is strict in his arrest. O I could tell you!
But let it be; Horatio I am dead,
Thou liuest, report me and my cause aright
To the vnsatisfied.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Neuer beleeue it;
I am more an antike Romane then a Dane,
Heere's yet some liquor left.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: As th'art a man
Giue me the cup, let goe, by heauen Ile hate,
O God Horatio! what a wounded name
Things standing thus vnknowne, shall I leaue behind me?
If thou didst euer hold me in thy heart,
Absent thee from felicity a while,

And in this harsh world draw thy breath in paineA march a
farre off.
To tell my story: what warlike noise is this?

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Young Fortinbrasse with conquest come from Poland,
Th th'embassadors of England giues this warlike volly.

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.l: O I die Horatio,
The potent poyson quite ore‐growes my spirit,
I cannot liue to heare the newes from England,
But I do prophesie the election lights
On Fortinbrasse, he has my dying voyce,
So tell him with th'occurants more and lesse
Which haue solicited, the rest is silence.

sp.speaker: Hlra.
sp.l: Now cracks a noble heart, good night sweet Prince,
And flight of Angels singe thee to thy rest.
Why dooes the drumme come hethe?

sp.speaker: Fortin.
sp.l: Where is this sight?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What is it you would see?
If ought of woe, or wonder, cease your search.

sp.speaker: Fortin.
sp.l: This quarry cries on hauock, O proud death
What feast is toward in thine eternall cell,
That thou so many Princes at a shot
So bloudily hast strooke?

sp.speaker: Embas.
sp.l: The sight is dismall
And our affaires from England come too late,
The eares are sencelesse rhat should giue vs hearing,
To tell him his commandement is fulfilld,
That Rosencraus and Guyldenstirne are dead,
Where should wee hae our thankes?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Not from his mouth
Had it th'ability of life to thanke you;
He neuer gaue commandement for their death;
But since so iump vpon this bloody question
You from the Pollock warres, and you from England
Are heere arriued, giue order that these bodies
High on a stage be placed to the view,
And let mee speake, to th'yet vnknowing wor ld
How these things came about; so shall you heare
Of cruell, bloody and vnnaturall acts.
Of accidentall iudgements, casuall slaughters,
Of deaths put on by cunning, and for no cause,
And in this vpshot, purposes mistooke,
Falne on the inuenters heads: all this can I
Truely deliuer.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Let vs hast to heare it,
And call the noblest to the audience,
For me with sorrow I embrace my fortune,
I haue some rights of memory in this kingdome,
Which now to claime my vantage doth inuite me.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Of that I shall haue also cause to speake,
And from his mouth, whose voyce will draw no more,
But let this same be presently perform'd
Euen while mens mindes are wilde, least more mischance
On plots and errors happen.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Let foure Captaines
Beare Hamlet like a souldier to the stage,
For he was likely, had he beene put on,
To haue prooued most royall; and for his passage
The souldiers musique and the right of warre
Speake loudly for him:
Take vp the bodies, such a sight as this,
Becomes the field, but heere showes much amisse.
Goe bid the souldiers shoote.exeunt.

p.add:
C
to Coy. to Stroke. from the Fr. Coy, quiet, still.

R
Recreant. Olde. An unbeliever, or Heretick; from the
It. Ricredente, says Skinner.
